eo.chatter: Almost 90 percent of The Banned at UT are from Iran. Only four of the seven countries affected by the executive order are represented on campus.

Most of them are in the U.S. on an F-1 student visa for full-time academic study. Others have J-1 exchange visitor visa status or H-1B specialty worker status. H-1B visa holders have a bachelor's degree or equivalent and are typically employed by the university in their area of study.
The ban would impact mostly graduate students and postdocs.
Three-quarters of them are in science, technology, engineering and mathematics fields; half are in the Cockrell School of Engineering.
Most had been at the university for three years or fewer when President Trump signed the original executive order. Five are new to the university this year.

source: University of Texas at Austin International Office
